title: Structured ionized winds shooting out from a quasar at relativistic speeds
author: Marc Audard
excerpt: Evidence indicates that supermassive black holes (SMBHs) exist at the centres of most galaxies. Their mass correlates with the galactic bulge mass1, suggesting a coevolution with their host galaxies2, most likely through powerful winds3. X-ray observations have detected highly ionized winds outflowing at sub-relativistic speeds from the accretion disks around SMBHs4,5. However, the limited spectral resolution of present X-ray instruments has left the physical structure and location of the winds poorly understood, hindering accurate estimates of their kinetic power6,7. Here the first X-Ray Imaging and Spectroscopy Mission (XRISM) observation of the luminous quasar PDS 456 is reported. The high-resolution spectrometer Resolve aboard XRISM enabled the discovery of five discrete velocity components outflowing at 20–30% of the speed of light. This demonstrates that the wind structure is highly inhomogeneous, which probably consists of up to a million clumps. The mass outflow rate is estimated to be 60–300 solar masses per year, with the wind kinetic power exceeding the Eddington luminosity limit. Compared with the galaxy-scale outflows, the kinetic power is more than three orders of magnitude larger, whereas the momentum flux is ten times larger. These estimates disfavour both energy-driven and momentum-driven outflow models. This suggests that such wind activity occurs in less than 10% of the quasar phase and/or that its energy/momentum is not efficiently transferred to the galaxy-scale outflows owing to the clumpiness of the wind and the interstellar medium. Observations of a luminous quasar from the high-resolution spectrometer Resolve aboard XRISM revealed highly inhomogeneous wind structure outflowing from a supermassive black hole, which probably consists of up to a million clumps.

Extended Data Fig. 1 X-ray light curves and hardness ratio of PDS 456 from the 2024 campaign.

The top-left panel shows the Swift XRT light curve from the period up to and including the XRISM observation, in which the intervals for the latter are marked by the vertical dotted lines. Time is plotted by Modified Julian Date (MJD). A large X-ray flare occurs 2 days before the start of the XRISM observation, at which the flux increased by a factor of about five. Before this, PDS 456 was in a historically low state compared with past observations. The top-right panel shows the corresponding light curves taken with XRISM Resolve and NuSTAR over the 2–10-keV and 3–40-keV bands, in which t = 0 corresponds to the start of the NuSTAR observation. The peak of the Swift flare was caught by both observatories in interval (i). Intervals (ii)–(iv) then follow the decline in flux. The XMM-Newton observation was performed in interval (iii). The bottom-left panels show the NuSTAR light curves and hardness ratio. The top and middle panels show the 3–6-keV and 10–30-keV band curves and the lower panel shows the hardness ratio (HRNuSTAR) light curve, in which HRNuSTAR was defined as CR10-30/CR3-6. Note that, despite the strong flux variability, there are no accompanying changes in the hardness ratio. Indeed, the lower panel shows the lack of any spectral variability over the whole observation. The bottom-right panel shows the ratio of the low-flux to high-flux Resolve spectra from 3 to 9 keV over the iron K band. The ratio spectrum is consistent with a constant factor of 0.3, which also implies that there is no strong spectral variability of the emission or absorption over the duration of the observations.

Extended Data Fig. 2 Zoom-in over the 3–40-keV NuSTAR light curve over the first 2 days of the observation to highlight the variability.

The interval Δt1 marks the rise portion of the curve, whereas Δt2 indicates the decline portion. From these, the timescale for the source flux to double (or half) was estimated to be 40 ks and implies an emission region of size D = 1.2 × 1015 cm from the light-crossing argument.

Extended Data Fig. 3 The SED of PDS 456 from the 2024 observations.

The black data points are from XMM-Newton EPIC-pn, the red points are from the simultaneous NuSTAR interval (iii) spectrum and the OM photometry points are shown in blue. Note that the last of these are corrected for galactic reddening. A simple double broken power-law function is used to describe the intrinsic continuum from the optical to hard X-rays (dotted black curve), whereas the SED without correction for absorption, as fitted to the data, is shown as the dotted magenta curve. After correction for absorption, the 1–1,000 Rydberg band luminosity of PDS 456 is 5 × 1046 erg s−1.

Extended Data Fig. 4 Geometry and coordinates assumed for the emission line profile.

A hemispherical shell radially outflowing is assumed for the calculation of the emission line profile. The blue hemisphere represents the outflowing shell above the accretion disk, which is inclined with an angle i.

Extended Data Fig. 5 Examples of the convolved emission line profile.

Left, convolved emission line profiles for an inclination angle of i = 15°. The black lines are the emission line profiles at E0 = 7.0 keV with a photon flux of N0 = 1 ph s−1 cm−2 keV−1 convolved with equation (3) for outflowing velocities ranging from 0.2c to 0.3c. The red line represents the averaged line profile, considering equal contributions from velocities of 0.2c–0.3c. Right, convolved emission line profiles for different inclination angles. The energy and velocities are the same as in the left plot.

Extended Data Fig. 6 The best-fit model applied to the observed spectra.

Left, the best-fit XSTAR model applied to the Resolve spectrum plotted over the iron K band. The total count rate Resolve spectrum is shown as black points versus the NXB model (blue), whereas the five-zone XSTAR model is shown as a red line. Each zone is numerically marked by order of increasing velocity. Note that the NXB is predicted to have only a minor impact on the resultant absorption profile, adding a small redward peak to absorber zone 3 (from Ni Kα) and infilling some of the absorber on the blue side of the zone 5 trough (owing to Cu Kα). Note that the Resolve spectrum is plotted in the observed frame (at z = 0) for comparison with the NXB model. Right, the best-fit model applied to the broadband spectrum. The Resolve data are shown in black (with grey errors), the Xtend data in blue and NuSTAR in red. The upper panel shows the fluxed spectra, folded through the instrumental responses, the lower panel the residuals of the data to the best-fitting absorber plus emission model and the inset shows a zoom-in of the model fitted to the Resolve data over the iron K band. The higher normalization of the NuSTAR spectrum is the result of its non-simultaneity, as it covers the brighter portion of the XRISM observation.

Extended Data Fig. 7 The variability of the broad iron K emission in response to the X-ray continuum, plotted for each of the four intervals.

The lower panel shows the 2–10-keV power-law flux, versus the iron line flux (middle panel) and its equivalent width (EW; lower panel) with respect to the continuum. The flux of the emission line does not seem to respond to the continuum, which results in the EW being anticorrelated with the continuum flux. Thus, the size scale of the emitter is required to be a minimum of six light days in extent.
